name: Josh Groban
description:
'''Joshua Winslow Groban''' (born February 27, 1981) is an American singer, songwriter, and actor. His first four solo albums have been certified [[Music recording certification|multi-platinum]], and he was charted in 2007 as the number-one best selling artist in the United States, with over 22.3 million records. {{as of|2022}}, he had sold over 25 million records worldwide.

Groban originally studied acting, but switched to singing as his voice developed. He attended the [[Los Angeles County High School for the Arts]], a free public school on the campus of [[California State University, Los Angeles]], where students receive a conservatory-style education. [[David Foster]] called him to stand in for [[Andrea Bocelli]] to rehearse a duet, "[[The Prayer (Celine Dion and Andrea Bocelli song)|The Prayer]]", with [[Celine Dion]] at the rehearsal for the 1999 [[Grammy Awards]]. [[Rosie O'Donnell]] immediately invited him to appear on her talk show. Foster asked him to sing at California Governor [[Gray Davis]]' 1999 inauguration. He was cast on ''[[Ally McBeal]]'' by the show's creator, [[David E. Kelley]], performing "[[Josh Groban (album)#track3|You're Still You]]", later released on [[Josh Groban (album)|his debut album]], for the [[Ally McBeal (season 4)#ep90|2001 season four finale]].

After his appearance in two professional productions of ''[[Chess (musical)|Chess]]'', he made his [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in 2016 as [[Pierre Bezukhov]] in the musical ''[[Natasha, Pierre & The Great Comet of 1812]]'', to critical acclaim and a [[Tony Awards|Tony Award]] nomination. In 2018, he received two [[Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations for his performance at the [[72nd Tony Awards]], and starred in the limited series ''[[The Good Cop (American TV series)|The Good Cop]]''. He also appeared in television series and films, such as ''[[Crazy, Stupid, Love]]'' and ''[[Muppets Most Wanted]]''.

In 2022, Groban portrayed the [[Beast (Disney character)|Beast]] in the television special ''[[Beauty and the Beast: A 30th Celebration]]''. He returned to Broadway in 2023 playing the [[Sweeney Todd|title character]] in a revival of ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street]]'', for which he earned his second Tony Award nomination.
